If a GPS height measurement is also available, then the height of the WGS-84 height datum used by the EKF can be corrected so that the height returned by the getLLH() function is compensated for primary height sensor drift and change in datum over time. The first two bit positions control when the height datum will be corrected. Correction is performed using a Bayes filter and only operates when GPS quality permits. The third bit position controls where the corrections to the GPS reference datum are applied. Corrections can be applied to the local vertical position or to the reported EKF origin height (default).
EK3_OGN_HGT_MASK.DisplayName: Bitmask control of EKF reference height correction

EK3_POSNE_M_NSE.Description: This sets the GPS horizontal position observation noise. Increasing it reduces the weighting of GPS horizontal position measurements.

EK3_POS_I_GATE.Description: This sets the percentage number of standard deviations applied to the GPS position measurement innovation consistency check. Decreasing it makes it more likely that good measurements will be rejected. Increasing it makes it more likely that bad measurements will be accepted.

EK3_RNG_I_GATE.Description: This sets the percentage number of standard deviations applied to the range finder innovation consistency check. Decreasing it makes it more likely that good measurements will be rejected. Increasing it makes it more likely that bad measurements will be accepted.

EK3_RNG_M_NSE.Description: This is the RMS value of noise in the range finder measurement. Increasing it reduces the weighting on this measurement.

EK3_RNG_USE_HGT.Description: The range finder will be used as the primary height source when below a specified percentage of the sensor maximum as set by the RNGFND_MAX_CM parameter. Set to -1 to prevent range finder use.

EK3_RNG_USE_SPD.Description: The range finder will not be used as the primary height source when the horizontal ground speed is greater than this value.

EK3_TAU_OUTPUT.Description: Sets the time constant of the output complementary filter/predictor in centi-seconds.

EK3_TERR_GRAD.Description: Specifies the maximum gradient of the terrain below the vehicle when it is using range finder as a height reference

EK3_VELD_M_NSE.Description: This sets a lower limit on the speed accuracy reported by the GPS receiver that is used to set vertical velocity observation noise. If the model of receiver used does not provide a speed accurcy estimate, then the parameter value will be used. Increasing it reduces the weighting of the GPS vertical velocity measurements.

EK3_VELNE_M_NSE.Description: This sets a lower limit on the speed accuracy reported by the GPS receiver that is used to set horizontal velocity observation noise. If the model of receiver used does not provide a speed accurcy estimate, then the parameter value will be used. Increasing it reduces the weighting of the GPS horizontal velocity measurements.

EK3_VEL_I_GATE.Description: This sets the percentage number of standard deviations applied to the GPS velocity measurement innovation consistency check. Decreasing it makes it more likely that good measurements willbe rejected. Increasing it makes it more likely that bad measurements will be accepted.

EK3_VIS_VERR_MAX.Description: This is the 1-STD odometry velocity observation error that will be assumed when minimum quality is reported by the sensor. When quality is between max and min, the error will be calculated using linear interpolation between VIS_VERR_MIN and VIS_VERR_MAX.

EK3_VIS_VERR_MIN.Description: This is the 1-STD odometry velocity observation error that will be assumed when maximum quality is reported by the sensor. When quality is between max and min, the error will be calculated using linear interpolation between VIS_VERR_MIN and VIS_VERR_MAX.

EK3_WENC_VERR.Description: This is the 1-STD odometry velocity observation error that will be assumed when wheel encoder data is being fused.

EK3_WIND_PSCALE.Description: This controls how much the process noise on the wind states is increased when gaining or losing altitude to take into account changes in wind speed and direction with altitude. Increasing this parameter increases how rapidly the wind states adapt when changing altitude, but does make wind velocity estimation noiser.
EK3_WIND_PSCALE.DisplayName: Height rate to wind process noise scaler

EK3_WIND_P_NSE.Description: This state process noise controls the growth of wind state error estimates. Increasing it makes wind estimation faster and noisier.

EK3_YAW_I_GATE.Description: This sets the percentage number of standard deviations applied to the magnetometer yaw measurement innovation consistency check. Decreasing it makes it more likely that good measurements will be rejected. Increasing it makes it more likely that bad measurements will be accepted.

EK3_YAW_M_NSE.Description: This is the RMS value of noise in yaw measurements from the magnetometer. Increasing it reduces the weighting on these measurements.

FENCE_ACTION.Description: What action should be taken when fence is breached

FENCE_ALT_MAX.Description: Maximum altitude allowed before geofence triggers

FENCE_ALT_MIN.Description: Minimum altitude allowed before geofence triggers

FENCE_ENABLE.Description: Allows you to enable (1) or disable (0) the fence functionality

FENCE_MARGIN.Description: Distance that autopilot's should maintain from the fence to avoid a breach

FENCE_RADIUS.Description: Circle fence radius which when breached will cause an RTL

FENCE_TOTAL.Description: Number of polygon points saved in eeprom (do not update manually)

FENCE_TYPE.Description: Enabled fence types held as bitmask

FHLD_BRAKE_RATE.Description: Controls deceleration rate on stick release

FHLD_FLOW_MAX.Description: Controls maximum apparent flow rate in flowhold

FHLD_QUAL_MIN.Description: Minimum flow quality to use flow position hold

FLOW_ADDR.Description: This is used to select between multiple possible I2C addresses for some sensor types. For PX4Flow you can choose 0 to 7 for the 8 possible addresses on the I2C bus.

FLOW_ENABLE.Description: Setting this to Enabled(1) will enable optical flow. Setting this to Disabled(0) will disable optical flow

FLOW_FXSCALER.Description: This sets the parts per thousand scale factor correction applied to the flow sensor X axis optical rate. It can be used to correct for variations in effective focal length. Each positive increment of 1 increases the scale factor applied to the X axis optical flow reading by 0.1%. Negative values reduce the scale factor.
FLOW_FXSCALER.DisplayName: X axis optical flow scale factor correction

FLOW_FYSCALER.Description: This sets the parts per thousand scale factor correction applied to the flow sensor Y axis optical rate. It can be used to correct for variations in effective focal length. Each positive increment of 1 increases the scale factor applied to the Y axis optical flow reading by 0.1%. Negative values reduce the scale factor.
FLOW_FYSCALER.DisplayName: Y axis optical flow scale factor correction

FLOW_ORIENT_YAW.Description: Specifies the number of centi-degrees that the flow sensor is yawed relative to the vehicle. A sensor with its X-axis pointing to the right of the vehicle X axis has a positive yaw angle.

FLOW_POS_X.Description: X position of the optical flow sensor focal point in body frame. Positive X is forward of the origin.

FLOW_POS_Y.Description: Y position of the optical flow sensor focal point in body frame. Positive Y is to the right of the origin.

FLOW_POS_Z.Description: Z position of the optical flow sensor focal point in body frame. Positive Z is down from the origin.

FOLL_DIST_MAX.Description: Follow distance maximum.  targets further than this will be ignored

FOLL_OFS_X.Description: Follow offsets in meters north/forward.  If positive, this vehicle fly ahead or north of lead vehicle.  Depends on FOLL_OFS_TYPE

FOLL_OFS_Y.Description: Follow offsets in meters east/right.  If positive, this vehicle fly to the right or east of lead vehicle.  Depends on FOLL_OFS_TYPE

FOLL_OFS_Z.Description: Follow offsets in meters down.  If positive, this vehicle fly below the lead vehicle

FOLL_POS_P.Description: Follow position error P gain.  Converts the difference between desired vertical speed and actual speed into a desired acceleration that is passed to the throttle acceleration controller

GND_ALT_OFFSET.Description: altitude offset in meters added to barometric altitude. This is used to allow for automatic adjustment of the base barometric altitude by a ground station equipped with a barometer. The value is added to the barometric altitude read by the aircraft. It is automatically reset to 0 when the barometer is calibrated on each reboot or when a preflight calibration is performed.

GND_EXT_BUS.Description: This selects the bus number for looking for an I2C barometer

GND_FLTR_RNG.Description: This sets the range around the average value that new samples must be within to be accepted. This can help reduce the impact of noise on sensors that are on long I2C cables. The value is a percentage from the average value. A value of zero disables this filter.
GND_FLTR_RNG.DisplayName: Range in which sample is accepted

GND_PRIMARY.Description: This selects which barometer will be the primary if multiple barometers are found

GND_SPEC_GRAV.Description: This sets the specific gravity of the fluid when flying an underwater ROV.

GND_TEMP.Description: User provided ambient ground temperature in degrees Celsius. This is used to improve the calculation of the altitude the vehicle is at. This parameter is not persistent and will be reset to 0 every time the vehicle is rebooted. A value of 0 means use the internal measurement ambient temperature.

GPS_AUTO_CONFIG.Description: Controls if the autopilot should automatically configure the GPS based on the parameters and default settings

GPS_AUTO_SWITCH.Description: Automatic switchover to GPS reporting best lock

GPS_BLEND_MASK.Description: Determines which of the accuracy measures Horizontal position, Vertical Position and Speed are used to calculate the weighting on each GPS receiver when soft switching has been selected by setting GPS_AUTO_SWITCH to 2

GPS_BLEND_TC.Description: Controls the slowest time constant applied to the calculation of GPS position and height offsets used to adjust different GPS receivers for steady state position differences.

GPS_DELAY_MS.Description: Controls the amount of GPS  measurement delay that the autopilot compensates for. Set to zero to use the default delay for the detected GPS type.

GPS_DELAY_MS2.Description: Controls the amount of GPS  measurement delay that the autopilot compensates for. Set to zero to use the default delay for the detected GPS type.

GPS_GNSS_MODE.Description: Bitmask for what GNSS system to use on the first GPS (all unchecked or zero to leave GPS as configured)

GPS_GNSS_MODE2.Description: Bitmask for what GNSS system to use on the second GPS (all unchecked or zero to leave GPS as configured)

GPS_INJECT_TO.Description: The GGS can send raw serial packets to inject data to multiple GPSes.

GPS_MIN_DGPS.Description: Sets the minimum type of differential GPS corrections required before allowing to switch into DGPS mode.
GPS_MIN_DGPS.DisplayName: Minimum Lock Type Accepted for DGPS

GPS_MIN_ELEV.Description: This sets the minimum elevation of satellites above the horizon for them to be used for navigation. Setting this to -100 leaves the minimum elevation set to the GPS modules default.

GPS_POS1_X.Description: X position of the first GPS antenna in body frame. Positive X is forward of the origin. Use antenna phase centroid location if provided by the manufacturer.

GPS_POS1_Y.Description: Y position of the first GPS antenna in body frame. Positive Y is to the right of the origin. Use antenna phase centroid location if provided by the manufacturer.

GPS_POS1_Z.Description: Z position of the first GPS antenna in body frame. Positive Z is down from the origin. Use antenna phase centroid location if provided by the manufacturer.

GPS_POS2_X.Description: X position of the second GPS antenna in body frame. Positive X is forward of the origin. Use antenna phase centroid location if provided by the manufacturer.

GPS_POS2_Y.Description: Y position of the second GPS antenna in body frame. Positive Y is to the right of the origin. Use antenna phase centroid location if provided by the manufacturer.

GPS_POS2_Z.Description: Z position of the second GPS antenna in body frame. Positive Z is down from the origin. Use antenna phase centroid location if provided by the manufacturer.

GPS_RATE_MS.Description: Controls how often the GPS should provide a position update. Lowering below 5Hz is not allowed

GPS_RATE_MS2.Description: Controls how often the GPS should provide a position update. Lowering below 5Hz is not allowed

GPS_RAW_DATA.Description: Handles logging raw data; on uBlox chips that support raw data this will log RXM messages into dataflash log; on Septentrio this will log on the equipment's SD card and when set to 2, the autopilot will try to stop logging after disarming and restart after arming

Values.5: Only log every five samples (uBlox only)

GPS_SAVE_CFG.Description: Determines whether the configuration for this GPS should be written to non-volatile memory on the GPS. Currently working for UBlox 6 series and above.

GPS_SBAS_MODE.Description: This sets the SBAS (satellite based augmentation system) mode if available on this GPS. If set to 2 then the SBAS mode is not changed in the GPS. Otherwise the GPS will be reconfigured to enable/disable SBAS. Disabling SBAS may be worthwhile in some parts of the world where an SBAS signal is available but the baseline is too long to be useful.

GPS_SBP_LOGMASK.Description: Masked with the SBP msg_type field to determine whether SBR1/SBR2 data is logged

GRIP_GRAB.Description: PWM value in microseconds sent to Gripper to initiate grabbing the cargo

GRIP_NEUTRAL.Description: PWM value in microseconds sent to grabber when not grabbing or releasing

GRIP_REGRAB.Description: Time in seconds that gripper will regrab the cargo to ensure grip has not weakened; 0 to disable

GRIP_RELEASE.Description: PWM value in microseconds sent to Gripper to release the cargo

H_COL2_MAX.Description: Highest possible servo position in PWM microseconds for the rear swashplate
H_COL2_MAX.DisplayName: Collective Pitch Maximum for rear swashplate

H_COL2_MID.Description: Swash servo position in PWM microseconds corresponding to zero collective pitch for the rear swashplate (or zero lift for Asymmetrical blades)
H_COL2_MID.DisplayName: Collective Pitch Mid-Point for rear swashplate

H_COL2_MIN.Description: Lowest possible servo position in PWM microseconds for the rear swashplate
H_COL2_MIN.DisplayName: Collective Pitch Minimum for rear swashplate

H_COLYAW.Description: Feed-forward compensation to automatically add rudder input when collective pitch is increased. Can be positive or negative depending on mechanics.

H_COL_CTRL_DIR.Description: Collective Control Direction - 0 for Normal. 1 for Reversed

H_COL_MAX.Description: Highest possible servo position in PWM microseconds for the swashplate

H_COL_MID.Description: Swash servo position in PWM microseconds corresponding to zero collective pitch (or zero lift for Asymmetrical blades)

H_COL_MIN.Description: Lowest possible servo position in PWM microseconds for the swashplate

H_CYC_MAX.Description: Maximum pitch angle of the swash plate

H_DCP_SCALER.Description: Scaling factor applied to the differential-collective-pitch

H_DCP_YAW.Description: Feed-forward compensation to automatically add yaw input when differential collective pitch is applied.

H_DUAL_MODE.Description: Sets the dual mode of the heli, either as tandem or as transverse.

H_FLYBAR_MODE.Description: Flybar present or not.  Affects attitude controller used during ACRO flight mode

H_GYR_GAIN.Description: PWM in microseconds sent to external gyro on ch7 when tail type is Servo w/ ExtGyro

H_GYR_GAIN_ACRO.Description: PWM in microseconds sent to external gyro on ch7 when tail type is Servo w/ ExtGyro. A value of zero means to use H_GYR_GAIN

H_LAND_COL_MIN.Description: Minimum collective position in PWM microseconds while landed or landing

H_PHANG.Description: Only for H3 swashplate.  If pitching the swash forward induces a roll, this can be correct the problem

H_PHANG1.Description: Phase angle correction for rotor head.  If pitching the swash forward induces a roll, this can be correct the problem

H_PHANG2.Description: Phase angle correction for rotor head.  If pitching the swash forward induces a roll, this can be correct the problem

H_RSC_CRITICAL.Description: Rotor speed below which flight is not possible

H_RSC_IDLE.Description: Rotor speed output while armed but rotor control speed is not engaged

H_RSC_MODE.Description: Determines the method of rotor speed control

H_RSC_RAMP_TIME.Description: Time in seconds for the output to the main rotor's ESC to reach full speed

H_RSC_RUNUP_TIME.Description: Time in seconds for the main rotor to reach full speed.  Must be longer than RSC_RAMP_TIME

H_RSC_SETPOINT.Description: PWM in microseconds passed to the external motor governor when external governor is enabled

H_RSC_SLEWRATE.Description: This controls the maximum rate at which the throttle output can change, as a percentage per second. A value of 100 means the throttle can change over its full range in one second. A value of zero gives unlimited slew rate.

H_RSC_THRCRV_0.Description: Throttle Servo Position for 0 percent collective. This is on a scale from 0 to 1000, where 1000 is full throttle and 0 is zero throttle. Actual PWM values are controlled by SERVOX_MIN and SERVOX_MAX. The 0 percent collective is defined by H_COL_MIN and 100 percent collective is defined by H_COL_MAX.
H_RSC_THRCRV_0.DisplayName: Throttle Servo Position for 0 percent collective

H_RSC_THRCRV_100.Description: Throttle Servo Position for 100 percent collective. This is on a scale from 0 to 1000, where 1000 is full throttle and 0 is zero throttle. Actual PWM values are controlled by SERVOX_MIN and SERVOX_MAX. The 0 percent collective is defined by H_COL_MIN and 100 percent collective is defined by H_COL_MAX.
H_RSC_THRCRV_100.DisplayName: Throttle Servo Position for 100 percent collective

H_RSC_THRCRV_25.Description: Throttle Servo Position for 25 percent collective. This is on a scale from 0 to 1000, where 1000 is full throttle and 0 is zero throttle. Actual PWM values are controlled by SERVOX_MIN and SERVOX_MAX. The 0 percent collective is defined by H_COL_MIN and 100 percent collective is defined by H_COL_MAX.
H_RSC_THRCRV_25.DisplayName: Throttle Servo Position for 25 percent collective

H_RSC_THRCRV_50.Description: Throttle Servo Position for 50 percent collective. This is on a scale from 0 to 1000, where 1000 is full throttle and 0 is zero throttle. Actual PWM values are controlled by SERVOX_MIN and SERVOX_MAX. The 0 percent collective is defined by H_COL_MIN and 100 percent collective is defined by H_COL_MAX.
H_RSC_THRCRV_50.DisplayName: Throttle Servo Position for 50 percent collective

H_RSC_THRCRV_75.Description: Throttle Servo Position for 75 percent collective. This is on a scale from 0 to 1000, where 1000 is full throttle and 0 is zero throttle. Actual PWM values are controlled by SERVOX_MIN and SERVOX_MAX. The 0 percent collective is defined by H_COL_MIN and 100 percent collective is defined by H_COL_MAX.
H_RSC_THRCRV_75.DisplayName: Throttle Servo Position for 75 percent collective

H_SV_MAN.Description: Manual servo override for swash set-up. Do not set this manually!

H_SV_TEST.Description: Number of cycles to run servo test on boot-up

H_TAIL_SPEED.Description: Direct Drive VarPitch Tail ESC speed in PWM microseconds.  Only used when TailType is DirectDrive VarPitch
H_TAIL_SPEED.DisplayName: Direct Drive VarPitch Tail ESC speed

H_TAIL_TYPE.Description: Tail type selection.  Simpler yaw controller used if external gyro is selected

H_YAW_SCALER.Description: Scaler for mixing yaw into roll or pitch.

IM_ACRO_COL_EXP.Description: Used to soften collective pitch inputs near center point in Acro mode.

IM_STAB_COL_1.Description: Helicopter's minimum collective pitch setting at zero throttle input in Stabilize mode

IM_STAB_COL_2.Description: Helicopter's collective pitch setting at mid-low throttle input in Stabilize mode

IM_STAB_COL_3.Description: Helicopter's collective pitch setting at mid-high throttle input in Stabilize mode

IM_STAB_COL_4.Description: Helicopter's maximum collective pitch setting at full throttle input in Stabilize mode

INS_ACC2OFFS_X.Description: Accelerometer2 offsets of X axis. This is setup using the acceleration calibration or level operations

INS_ACC2OFFS_Y.Description: Accelerometer2 offsets of Y axis. This is setup using the acceleration calibration or level operations

INS_ACC2OFFS_Z.Description: Accelerometer2 offsets of Z axis. This is setup using the acceleration calibration or level operations

INS_ACC2SCAL_X.Description: Accelerometer2 scaling of X axis.  Calculated during acceleration calibration routine

INS_ACC2SCAL_Y.Description: Accelerometer2 scaling of Y axis  Calculated during acceleration calibration routine

INS_ACC2SCAL_Z.Description: Accelerometer2 scaling of Z axis  Calculated during acceleration calibration routine

INS_ACC2_ID.Description: Accelerometer2 sensor ID, taking into account its type, bus and instance

INS_ACC3OFFS_X.Description: Accelerometer3 offsets of X axis. This is setup using the acceleration calibration or level operations

INS_ACC3OFFS_Y.Description: Accelerometer3 offsets of Y axis. This is setup using the acceleration calibration or level operations

INS_ACC3OFFS_Z.Description: Accelerometer3 offsets of Z axis. This is setup using the acceleration calibration or level operations

INS_ACC3SCAL_X.Description: Accelerometer3 scaling of X axis.  Calculated during acceleration calibration routine

INS_ACC3SCAL_Y.Description: Accelerometer3 scaling of Y axis  Calculated during acceleration calibration routine

INS_ACC3SCAL_Z.Description: Accelerometer3 scaling of Z axis  Calculated during acceleration calibration routine

INS_ACC3_ID.Description: Accelerometer3 sensor ID, taking into account its type, bus and instance

INS_ACCEL_FILTER.Description: Filter cutoff frequency for accelerometers. This can be set to a lower value to try to cope with very high vibration levels in aircraft. This option takes effect on the next reboot. A value of zero means no filtering (not recommended!)

INS_ACCOFFS_X.Description: Accelerometer offsets of X axis. This is setup using the acceleration calibration or level operations

INS_ACCOFFS_Y.Description: Accelerometer offsets of Y axis. This is setup using the acceleration calibration or level operations

INS_ACCOFFS_Z.Description: Accelerometer offsets of Z axis. This is setup using the acceleration calibration or level operations

INS_ACCSCAL_X.Description: Accelerometer scaling of X axis.  Calculated during acceleration calibration routine

INS_ACCSCAL_Y.Description: Accelerometer scaling of Y axis  Calculated during acceleration calibration routine

INS_ACCSCAL_Z.Description: Accelerometer scaling of Z axis  Calculated during acceleration calibration routine

INS_ACC_BODYFIX.Description: The body-fixed accelerometer to be used for trim calculation

INS_ACC_ID.Description: Accelerometer sensor ID, taking into account its type, bus and instance

INS_FAST_SAMPLE.Description: Mask of IMUs to enable fast sampling on, if available

INS_GYR2OFFS_X.Description: Gyro2 sensor offsets of X axis. This is setup on each boot during gyro calibrations

INS_GYR2OFFS_Y.Description: Gyro2 sensor offsets of Y axis. This is setup on each boot during gyro calibrations

INS_GYR2OFFS_Z.Description: Gyro2 sensor offsets of Z axis. This is setup on each boot during gyro calibrations

INS_GYR2_ID.Description: Gyro2 sensor ID, taking into account its type, bus and instance

INS_GYR3OFFS_X.Description: Gyro3 sensor offsets of X axis. This is setup on each boot during gyro calibrations

INS_GYR3OFFS_Y.Description: Gyro3 sensor offsets of Y axis. This is setup on each boot during gyro calibrations

INS_GYR3OFFS_Z.Description: Gyro3 sensor offsets of Z axis. This is setup on each boot during gyro calibrations

INS_GYR3_ID.Description: Gyro3 sensor ID, taking into account its type, bus and instance

INS_GYROFFS_X.Description: Gyro sensor offsets of X axis. This is setup on each boot during gyro calibrations

INS_GYROFFS_Y.Description: Gyro sensor offsets of Y axis. This is setup on each boot during gyro calibrations

INS_GYROFFS_Z.Description: Gyro sensor offsets of Z axis. This is setup on each boot during gyro calibrations

INS_GYRO_FILTER.Description: Filter cutoff frequency for gyroscopes. This can be set to a lower value to try to cope with very high vibration levels in aircraft. This option takes effect on the next reboot. A value of zero means no filtering (not recommended!)

INS_GYR_CAL.Description: Conrols when automatic gyro calibration is performed

INS_GYR_ID.Description: Gyro sensor ID, taking into account its type, bus and instance

INS_POS1_X.Description: X position of the first IMU Accelerometer in body frame. Positive X is forward of the origin. Attention: The IMU should be located as close to the vehicle c.g. as practical so that the value of this parameter is minimised. Failure to do so can result in noisy navigation velocity measurements due to vibration and IMU gyro noise. If the IMU cannot be moved and velocity noise is a problem, a location closer to the IMU can be used as the body frame origin.

INS_POS1_Y.Description: Y position of the first IMU accelerometer in body frame. Positive Y is to the right of the origin. Attention: The IMU should be located as close to the vehicle c.g. as practical so that the value of this parameter is minimised. Failure to do so can result in noisy navigation velocity measurements due to vibration and IMU gyro noise. If the IMU cannot be moved and velocity noise is a problem, a location closer to the IMU can be used as the body frame origin.

INS_POS1_Z.Description: Z position of the first IMU accelerometer in body frame. Positive Z is down from the origin. Attention: The IMU should be located as close to the vehicle c.g. as practical so that the value of this parameter is minimised. Failure to do so can result in noisy navigation velocity measurements due to vibration and IMU gyro noise. If the IMU cannot be moved and velocity noise is a problem, a location closer to the IMU can be used as the body frame origin.

INS_POS2_X.Description: X position of the second IMU accelerometer in body frame. Positive X is forward of the origin. Attention: The IMU should be located as close to the vehicle c.g. as practical so that the value of this parameter is minimised. Failure to do so can result in noisy navigation velocity measurements due to vibration and IMU gyro noise. If the IMU cannot be moved and velocity noise is a problem, a location closer to the IMU can be used as the body frame origin.

INS_POS2_Y.Description: Y position of the second IMU accelerometer in body frame. Positive Y is to the right of the origin. Attention: The IMU should be located as close to the vehicle c.g. as practical so that the value of this parameter is minimised. Failure to do so can result in noisy navigation velocity measurements due to vibration and IMU gyro noise. If the IMU cannot be moved and velocity noise is a problem, a location closer to the IMU can be used as the body frame origin.

INS_POS2_Z.Description: Z position of the second IMU accelerometer in body frame. Positive Z is down from the origin. Attention: The IMU should be located as close to the vehicle c.g. as practical so that the value of this parameter is minimised. Failure to do so can result in noisy navigation velocity measurements due to vibration and IMU gyro noise. If the IMU cannot be moved and velocity noise is a problem, a location closer to the IMU can be used as the body frame origin.

INS_POS3_X.Description: X position of the third IMU accelerometer in body frame. Positive X is forward of the origin. Attention: The IMU should be located as close to the vehicle c.g. as practical so that the value of this parameter is minimised. Failure to do so can result in noisy navigation velocity measurements due to vibration and IMU gyro noise. If the IMU cannot be moved and velocity noise is a problem, a location closer to the IMU can be used as the body frame origin.

INS_POS3_Y.Description: Y position of the third IMU accelerometer in body frame. Positive Y is to the right of the origin. Attention: The IMU should be located as close to the vehicle c.g. as practical so that the value of this parameter is minimised. Failure to do so can result in noisy navigation velocity measurements due to vibration and IMU gyro noise. If the IMU cannot be moved and velocity noise is a problem, a location closer to the IMU can be used as the body frame origin.

INS_POS3_Z.Description: Z position of the third IMU accelerometer in body frame. Positive Z is down from the origin. Attention: The IMU should be located as close to the vehicle c.g. as practical so that the value of this parameter is minimised. Failure to do so can result in noisy navigation velocity measurements due to vibration and IMU gyro noise. If the IMU cannot be moved and velocity noise is a problem, a location closer to the IMU can be used as the body frame origin.

INS_STILL_THRESH.Description: Threshold to tolerate vibration to determine if vehicle is motionless. This depends on the frame type and if there is a constant vibration due to motors before launch or after landing. Total motionless is about 0.05. Suggested values: Planes/rover use 0.1, multirotors use 1, tradHeli uses 5
INS_STILL_THRESH.DisplayName: Stillness threshold for detecting if we are moving

INS_TRIM_OPTION.Description: Specifies how the accel cal routine determines the trims

Values.2: Assume ACC_BODYFIX is perfectly aligned to the vehicle

INS_USE.Description: Use first IMU for attitude, velocity and position estimates
INS_USE.DisplayName: Use first IMU for attitude, velocity and position estimates

INS_USE2.Description: Use second IMU for attitude, velocity and position estimates
INS_USE2.DisplayName: Use second IMU for attitude, velocity and position estimates

INS_USE3.Description: Use third IMU for attitude, velocity and position estimates
INS_USE3.DisplayName: Use third IMU for attitude, velocity and position estimates

INS_LOG_BAT_CNT.Description: Number of samples to take when logging streams of IMU sensor readings.  Will be rounded down to a multiple of 32.

INS_LOG_BAT_LGCT.Description: Number of samples to push to count every INS_LOG_BAT_LGIN

INS_LOG_BAT_LGIN.Description: Interval between pushing samples to the DataFlash log

INS_LOG_BAT_MASK.Description: Bitmap of which IMUs to log batch data for

Bitmask.0: Sensor-Rate Logging (sample at full sensor rate seen by AP)

LGR_SERVO_DEPLOY.Description: Servo PWM value in microseconds when landing gear is deployed
LGR_SERVO_DEPLOY.DisplayName: Landing Gear Servo Deployed PWM Value

LGR_SERVO_RTRACT.Description: Servo PWM value in microseconds when landing gear is retracted
LGR_SERVO_RTRACT.DisplayName: Landing Gear Servo Retracted PWM Value

LOG_BACKEND_TYPE.Description: 0 for None, 1 for File, 2 for dataflash mavlink, 3 for both file and dataflash

LOG_DISARMED.Description: If LOG_DISARMED is set to 1 then logging will be enabled while disarmed. This can make for very large logfiles but can help a lot when tracking down startup issues

LOG_FILE_BUFSIZE.Description: The DataFlash_File backend uses a buffer to store data before writing to the block device.  Raising this value may reduce "gaps" in your SD card logging.  This buffer size may be reduced depending on available memory.  PixHawk requires at least 4 kilobytes.  Maximum value available here is 64 kilobytes.
LOG_FILE_BUFSIZE.DisplayName: Maximum DataFlash File Backend buffer size (in kilobytes)

LOG_FILE_DSRMROT.Description: When set, the current log file is closed when the vehicle is disarmed.  If LOG_DISARMED is set then a fresh log will be opened.
LOG_FILE_DSRMROT.DisplayName: Stop logging to current file on disarm

LOG_MAV_BUFSIZE.Description: Maximum amount of memory to allocate to DataFlash-over-mavlink
LOG_MAV_BUFSIZE.DisplayName: Maximum DataFlash MAVLink Backend buffer size

LOG_REPLAY.Description: If LOG_REPLAY is set to 1 then the EKF2 state estimator will log detailed information needed for diagnosing problems with the Kalman filter. It is suggested that you also raise LOG_FILE_BUFSIZE to give more buffer space for logging and use a high quality microSD card to ensure no sensor data is lost
LOG_REPLAY.DisplayName: Enable logging of information needed for Replay

LOIT_ACC_MAX.Description: Loiter maximum correction acceleration in cm/s/s.  Higher values cause the copter to correct position errors more aggressively.

LOIT_ANG_MAX.Description: Loiter maximum lean angle. Set to zero for 2/3 of PSC_ANGLE_MAX or ANGLE_MAX

LOIT_BRK_ACCEL.Description: Loiter braking acceleration in cm/s/s. Higher values stop the copter more quickly when the stick is centered.

LOIT_BRK_JERK.Description: Loiter braking jerk in cm/s/s/s. Higher values will remove braking faster if the pilot moves the sticks during a braking manuver.

LOIT_SPEED.Description: Defines the maximum speed in cm/s which the aircraft will travel horizontally while in loiter mode

MIS_OPTIONS.Description: Bitmask of what options to use in missions.

MIS_RESTART.Description: Controls mission starting point when entering Auto mode (either restart from beginning of mission or resume from last command run)
MIS_RESTART.DisplayName: Mission Restart when entering Auto mode

MIS_TOTAL.Description: The number of mission mission items that has been loaded by the ground station. Do not change this manually.

MNT2_ANGMAX_PAN.Description: MOunt2's maximum physical pan (yaw) angular position

MNT2_ANGMAX_ROL.Description: Mount2's maximum physical roll angular position

MNT2_ANGMAX_TIL.Description: Mount2's maximum physical tilt (pitch) angular position

MNT2_ANGMIN_PAN.Description: Mount2's minimum physical pan (yaw) angular position

MNT2_ANGMIN_ROL.Description: Mount2's minimum physical roll angular position

MNT2_ANGMIN_TIL.Description: Mount2's minimum physical tilt (pitch) angular position

MNT2_DEFLT_MODE.Description: Mount default operating mode on startup and after control is returned from autopilot

MNT2_LEAD_PTCH.Description: Causes the servo angle output to lead the current angle of the vehicle by some amount of time based on current angular rate. Increase until the servo is responsive but doesn't overshoot. Does nothing with pan stabilization enabled.

MNT2_LEAD_RLL.Description: Causes the servo angle output to lead the current angle of the vehicle by some amount of time based on current angular rate, compensating for servo delay. Increase until the servo is responsive but doesn't overshoot. Does nothing with pan stabilization enabled.

MNT2_NEUTRAL_X.Description: Mount2 roll angle when in neutral position
MNT2_NEUTRAL_X.DisplayName: Mount2 roll angle when in neutral position

MNT2_NEUTRAL_Y.Description: Mount2 tilt/pitch angle when in neutral position
MNT2_NEUTRAL_Y.DisplayName: Mount2 tilt/pitch angle when in neutral position

MNT2_NEUTRAL_Z.Description: Mount2 pan/yaw angle when in neutral position
MNT2_NEUTRAL_Z.DisplayName: Mount2 pan/yaw angle when in neutral position

MNT2_RC_IN_PAN.Description: 0 for none, any other for the RC channel to be used to control pan (yaw) movements

MNT2_RC_IN_ROLL.Description: 0 for none, any other for the RC channel to be used to control roll movements

MNT2_RC_IN_TILT.Description: 0 for none, any other for the RC channel to be used to control tilt (pitch) movements

MNT2_RETRACT_X.Description: Mount2 roll angle when in retracted position
MNT2_RETRACT_X.DisplayName: Mount2 roll angle when in retracted position

MNT2_RETRACT_Y.Description: Mount2 tilt/pitch angle when in retracted position
MNT2_RETRACT_Y.DisplayName: Mount2 tilt/pitch angle when in retracted position

MNT2_RETRACT_Z.Description: Mount2 yaw/pan angle when in retracted position
MNT2_RETRACT_Z.DisplayName: Mount2 yaw/pan angle when in retracted position

MNT2_STAB_PAN.Description: enable pan/yaw stabilisation relative to Earth

MNT2_STAB_ROLL.Description: enable roll stabilisation relative to Earth

MNT2_STAB_TILT.Description: enable tilt/pitch stabilisation relative to Earth

MNT_ANGMAX_PAN.Description: Maximum physical pan (yaw) angular position of the mount

MNT_ANGMAX_ROL.Description: Maximum physical roll angular position of the mount

MNT_ANGMAX_TIL.Description: Maximum physical tilt (pitch) angular position of the mount

MNT_ANGMIN_PAN.Description: Minimum physical pan (yaw) angular position of mount.

MNT_ANGMIN_ROL.Description: Minimum physical roll angular position of mount.

MNT_ANGMIN_TIL.Description: Minimum physical tilt (pitch) angular position of mount.

MNT_DEFLT_MODE.Description: Mount default operating mode on startup and after control is returned from autopilot

MNT_JSTICK_SPD.Description: 0 for position control, small for low speeds, 100 for max speed. A good general value is 10 which gives a movement speed of 3 degrees per second.

MNT_LEAD_PTCH.Description: Causes the servo angle output to lead the current angle of the vehicle by some amount of time based on current angular rate. Increase until the servo is responsive but doesn't overshoot. Does nothing with pan stabilization enabled.

MNT_LEAD_RLL.Description: Causes the servo angle output to lead the current angle of the vehicle by some amount of time based on current angular rate, compensating for servo delay. Increase until the servo is responsive but doesn't overshoot. Does nothing with pan stabilization enabled.

MNT_NEUTRAL_X.Description: Mount roll angle when in neutral position
MNT_NEUTRAL_X.DisplayName: Mount roll angle when in neutral position

MNT_NEUTRAL_Y.Description: Mount tilt/pitch angle when in neutral position
MNT_NEUTRAL_Y.DisplayName: Mount tilt/pitch angle when in neutral position

MNT_NEUTRAL_Z.Description: Mount pan/yaw angle when in neutral position
MNT_NEUTRAL_Z.DisplayName: Mount pan/yaw angle when in neutral position

MNT_RC_IN_PAN.Description: 0 for none, any other for the RC channel to be used to control pan (yaw) movements

MNT_RC_IN_ROLL.Description: 0 for none, any other for the RC channel to be used to control roll movements

MNT_RC_IN_TILT.Description: 0 for none, any other for the RC channel to be used to control tilt (pitch) movements

MNT_RETRACT_X.Description: Mount roll angle when in retracted position
MNT_RETRACT_X.DisplayName: Mount roll angle when in retracted position

MNT_RETRACT_Y.Description: Mount tilt/pitch angle when in retracted position
MNT_RETRACT_Y.DisplayName: Mount tilt/pitch angle when in retracted position

MNT_RETRACT_Z.Description: Mount yaw/pan angle when in retracted position
MNT_RETRACT_Z.DisplayName: Mount yaw/pan angle when in retracted position

MNT_STAB_PAN.Description: enable pan/yaw stabilisation relative to Earth

MNT_STAB_ROLL.Description: enable roll stabilisation relative to Earth

MNT_STAB_TILT.Description: enable tilt/pitch stabilisation relative to Earth

MOT_BAT_CURR_MAX.Description: Maximum current over which maximum throttle is limited (0 = Disabled)

MOT_BAT_CURR_TC.Description: Time constant used to limit the maximum current

MOT_BAT_IDX.Description: Which battery monitor should be used for doing compensation

MOT_BAT_VOLT_MAX.Description: Battery voltage compensation maximum voltage (voltage above this will have no additional scaling effect on thrust).  Recommend 4.4 * cell count, 0 = Disabled

MOT_BAT_VOLT_MIN.Description: Battery voltage compensation minimum voltage (voltage below this will have no additional scaling effect on thrust).  Recommend 3.5 * cell count, 0 = Disabled

MOT_BOOST_SCALE.Description: This is a scaling factor for vehicles with a vertical booster motor used for extra lift. It is used with electric multicopters that have an internal combusion booster motor for longer endurance. The output to the BoostThrottle servo function is set to the current motor thottle times this scaling factor. A higher scaling factor will put more of the load on the booster motor. A value of 1 will set the BoostThrottle equal to the main throttle.

MOT_HOVER_LEARN.Description: Enable/Disable automatic learning of hover throttle

MOT_PWM_MAX.Description: This sets the max PWM value in microseconds that will ever be output to the motors, 0 = use input RC3_MAX

MOT_PWM_MIN.Description: This sets the min PWM output value in microseconds that will ever be output to the motors, 0 = use input RC3_MIN

MOT_PWM_TYPE.Description: This selects the output PWM type, allowing for normal PWM continuous output, OneShot, brushed or DShot motor output

MOT_SAFE_DISARM.Description: Disables motor PWM output when disarmed
MOT_SAFE_DISARM.DisplayName: Motor PWM output disabled when disarmed

MOT_SPIN_ARM.Description: Point at which the motors start to spin expressed as a number from 0 to 1 in the entire output range.  Should be lower than MOT_SPIN_MIN.

MOT_SPIN_MAX.Description: Point at which the thrust saturates expressed as a number from 0 to 1 in the entire output range

MOT_SPIN_MIN.Description: Point at which the thrust starts expressed as a number from 0 to 1 in the entire output range.  Should be higher than MOT_SPIN_ARM.

MOT_SPOOL_TIME.Description: Time in seconds to spool up the motors from zero to min throttle.

MOT_THST_EXPO.Description: Motor thrust curve exponent (from 0 for linear to 1.0 for second order curve)

MOT_THST_HOVER.Description: Motor thrust needed to hover expressed as a number from 0 to 1

MOT_YAW_HEADROOM.Description: Yaw control is given at least this pwm in microseconds range

NTF_BUZZ_ENABLE.Description: Enable or disable the buzzer. Only for Linux and PX4 based boards.

NTF_BUZZ_PIN.Description: Enables to connect active buzzer to arbitrary pin. Requires 3-pin buzzer or additional MOSFET!

NTF_DISPLAY_TYPE.Description: This sets up the type of on-board I2C display. Disabled by default.

NTF_LED_BRIGHT.Description: Select the RGB LED brightness level. When USB is connected brightness will never be higher than low regardless of the setting.

NTF_LED_OVERRIDE.Description: This sets up the board RGB LED for override by MAVLink. Normal notify LED control is disabled

NTF_OREO_THEME.Description: Enable/Disable Solo Oreo LED driver, 0 to disable, 1 for Aircraft theme, 2 for Rover theme

PLND_ACC_P_NSE.Description: Kalman Filter Accelerometer Noise, higher values weight the input from the camera more, accels less

PLND_BUS.Description: Precland sensor bus for I2C sensors.

PLND_CAM_POS_X.Description: X position of the camera in body frame. Positive X is forward of the origin.

PLND_CAM_POS_Y.Description: Y position of the camera in body frame. Positive Y is to the right of the origin.

PLND_CAM_POS_Z.Description: Z position of the camera in body frame. Positive Z is down from the origin.

PLND_EST_TYPE.Description: Specifies the estimation method to be used

PLND_LAND_OFS_X.Description: Desired landing position of the camera forward of the target in vehicle body frame

PLND_LAND_OFS_Y.Description: desired landing position of the camera right of the target in vehicle body frame

PLND_YAW_ALIGN.Description: Yaw angle from body x-axis to sensor x-axis.

PRX2_TYPE.Description: What type of proximity sensor is connected

PRX_TYPE.Description: What type of proximity sensor is connected

PSC_ACCZ_D.Description: Acceleration (vertical) controller D gain.  Compensates for short-term change in desired vertical acceleration vs actual acceleration

PSC_ACCZ_FILT.Description: Filter applied to acceleration to reduce noise.  Lower values reduce noise but add delay.

PSC_ACCZ_I.Description: Acceleration (vertical) controller I gain.  Corrects long-term difference in desired vertical acceleration and actual acceleration

PSC_ACCZ_IMAX.Description: Acceleration (vertical) controller I gain maximum.  Constrains the maximum pwm that the I term will generate

PSC_ACCZ_P.Description: Acceleration (vertical) controller P gain.  Converts the difference between desired vertical acceleration and actual acceleration into a motor output

PSC_ACC_XY_FILT.Description: Lower values will slow the response of the navigation controller and reduce twitchiness

PSC_ANGLE_MAX.Description: Maximum lean angle autopilot can request.  Set to zero to use ANGLE_MAX parameter value

PSC_POSXY_P.Description: Position controller P gain.  Converts the distance (in the latitude direction) to the target location into a desired speed which is then passed to the loiter latitude rate controller

PSC_POSZ_P.Description: Position (vertical) controller P gain.  Converts the difference between the desired altitude and actual altitude into a climb or descent rate which is passed to the throttle rate controller

PSC_VELXY_D.Description: Velocity (horizontal) D gain.  Corrects short-term changes in velocity

PSC_VELXY_D_FILT.Description: Velocity (horizontal) input filter.  This filter (in hz) is applied to the input for P and I terms

PSC_VELXY_FILT.Description: Velocity (horizontal) input filter.  This filter (in hz) is applied to the input for P and I terms

PSC_VELXY_I.Description: Velocity (horizontal) I gain.  Corrects long-term difference in desired velocity to a target acceleration

PSC_VELXY_IMAX.Description: Velocity (horizontal) integrator maximum.  Constrains the target acceleration that the I gain will output

PSC_VELXY_P.Description: Velocity (horizontal) P gain.  Converts the difference between desired velocity to a target acceleration

PSC_VELZ_P.Description: Velocity (vertical) controller P gain.  Converts the difference between desired vertical speed and actual speed into a desired acceleration that is passed to the throttle acceleration controller

RALLY_INCL_HOME.Description: Controls if Home is included as a Rally point (i.e. as a safe landing place) for RTL

RALLY_LIMIT_KM.Description: Maximum distance to rally point. If the closest rally point is more than this number of kilometers from the current position and the home location is closer than any of the rally points from the current position then do RTL to home rather than to the closest rally point. This prevents a leftover rally point from a different airfield being used accidentally. If this is set to 0 then the closest rally point is always used.

RALLY_TOTAL.Description: Number of rally points currently loaded

RC10_MIN.Description: RC minimum PWM pulse width in microseconds. Typically 1000 is lower limit, 1500 is neutral and 2000 is upper limit.

RC10_REVERSED.Description: Reverse channel input. Set to 0 for normal operation. Set to 1 to reverse this input channel.

RC10_TRIM.Description: RC trim (neutral) PWM pulse width in microseconds. Typically 1000 is lower limit, 1500 is neutral and 2000 is upper limit.

RCMAP_FORWARD.Description: Forward channel number. This is useful when you have a RC transmitter that can't change the channel order easily. Forward is normally on channel 5, but you can move it to any channel with this parameter. Reboot is required for changes to take effect.

RCMAP_LATERAL.Description: Lateral channel number. This is useful when you have a RC transmitter that can't change the channel order easily. Lateral is normally on channel 6, but you can move it to any channel with this parameter. Reboot is required for changes to take effect.

RCMAP_PITCH.Description: Pitch channel number. This is useful when you have a RC transmitter that can't change the channel order easily. Pitch is normally on channel 2, but you can move it to any channel with this parameter.  Reboot is required for changes to take effect.

RCMAP_ROLL.Description: Roll channel number. This is useful when you have a RC transmitter that can't change the channel order easily. Roll is normally on channel 1, but you can move it to any channel with this parameter.  Reboot is required for changes to take effect.

RCMAP_THROTTLE.Description: Throttle channel number. This is useful when you have a RC transmitter that can't change the channel order easily. Throttle is normally on channel 3, but you can move it to any channel with this parameter. Warning APM 2.X: Changing the throttle channel could produce unexpected fail-safe results if connection between receiver and on-board PPM Encoder is lost. Disabling on-board PPM Encoder is recommended.  Reboot is required for changes to take effect.

RCMAP_YAW.Description: Yaw channel number. This is useful when you have a RC transmitter that can't change the channel order easily. Yaw (also known as rudder) is normally on channel 4, but you can move it to any channel with this parameter.  Reboot is required for changes to take effect.

RELAY_DEFAULT.Description: The state of the relay on boot.

RELAY_PIN.Description: Digital pin number for first relay control. This is the pin used for camera control.

RELAY_PIN2.Description: Digital pin number for 2nd relay control.

RELAY_PIN3.Description: Digital pin number for 3rd relay control.

RELAY_PIN4.Description: Digital pin number for 4th relay control.

RNGFND2_ADDR.Description: This sets the bus address of the sensor, where applicable. Used for the LightWare I2C sensor to allow for multiple sensors on different addresses. A value of 0 disables the sensor.

RNGFND2_FUNCTION.Description: Control over what function is used to calculate distance. For a linear function, the distance is (voltage-offset)*scaling. For a inverted function the distance is (offset-voltage)*scaling. For a hyperbolic function the distance is scaling/(voltage-offset). The functions return the distance in meters.

RNGFND2_GNDCLEAR.Description: This parameter sets the expected range measurement(in cm) that the second range finder should return when the vehicle is on the ground.
RNGFND2_GNDCLEAR.DisplayName: Distance (in cm) from the second range finder to the ground

RNGFND2_MAX_CM.Description: Maximum distance in centimeters that rangefinder can reliably read

RNGFND2_MIN_CM.Description: Minimum distance in centimeters that rangefinder can reliably read

RNGFND2_OFFSET.Description: Offset in volts for zero distance

RNGFND2_PIN.Description: Analog pin that rangefinder is connected to. Set this to 0..9 for the APM2 analog pins. Set to 64 on an APM1 for the dedicated 'airspeed' port on the end of the board. Set to 11 on PX4 for the analog 'airspeed' port. Set to 15 on the Pixhawk for the analog 'airspeed' port.

RNGFND2_POS_X.Description: X position of the second rangefinder in body frame. Positive X is forward of the origin. Use the zero range datum point if supplied.

RNGFND2_POS_Y.Description: Y position of the second rangefinder in body frame. Positive Y is to the right of the origin. Use the zero range datum point if supplied.

RNGFND2_POS_Z.Description: Z position of the second rangefinder in body frame. Positive Z is down from the origin. Use the zero range datum point if supplied.

RNGFND2_RMETRIC.Description: This parameter sets whether an analog rangefinder is ratiometric. Most analog rangefinders are ratiometric, meaning that their output voltage is influenced by the supply voltage. Some analog rangefinders (such as the SF/02) have their own internal voltage regulators so they are not ratiometric.

RNGFND2_SCALING.Description: Scaling factor between rangefinder reading and distance. For the linear and inverted functions this is in meters per volt. For the hyperbolic function the units are meterVolts.

RNGFND2_SETTLE.Description: The time in milliseconds that the rangefinder reading takes to settle. This is only used when a STOP_PIN is specified. It determines how long we have to wait for the rangefinder to give a reading after we set the STOP_PIN high. For a sonar rangefinder with a range of around 7m this would need to be around 50 milliseconds to allow for the sonar pulse to travel to the target and back again.

RNGFND2_STOP_PIN.Description: Digital pin that enables/disables rangefinder measurement for an analog rangefinder. A value of -1 means no pin. If this is set, then the pin is set to 1 to enable the rangefinder and set to 0 to disable it. This can be used to ensure that multiple sonar rangefinders don't interfere with each other.

RNGFND2_TYPE.Description: What type of rangefinder device that is connected

RNGFND3_ADDR.Description: This sets the bus address of the sensor, where applicable. Used for the LightWare I2C sensor to allow for multiple sensors on different addresses. A value of 0 disables the sensor.

RNGFND3_FUNCTION.Description: Control over what function is used to calculate distance. For a linear function, the distance is (voltage-offset)*scaling. For a inverted function the distance is (offset-voltage)*scaling. For a hyperbolic function the distance is scaling/(voltage-offset). The functions return the distance in meters.

RNGFND3_GNDCLEAR.Description: This parameter sets the expected range measurement(in cm) that the third range finder should return when the vehicle is on the ground.

RNGFND3_MIN_CM.Description: Minimum distance in centimeters that rangefinder can reliably read

RNGFND_GNDCLEAR.Description: This parameter sets the expected range measurement(in cm) that the range finder should return when the vehicle is on the ground.
RNGFND_GNDCLEAR.DisplayName: Distance (in cm) from the range finder to the ground

RNGFND_MAX_CM.Description: Maximum distance in centimeters that rangefinder can reliably read

RNGFND_MIN_CM.Description: Minimum distance in centimeters that rangefinder can reliably read

RNGFND_OFFSET.Description: Offset in volts for zero distance for analog rangefinders. Offset added to distance in centimeters for PWM and I2C Lidars

RNGFND_PIN.Description: Analog pin that rangefinder is connected to. Set this to 0..9 for the APM2 analog pins. Set to 64 on an APM1 for the dedicated 'airspeed' port on the end of the board. Set to 11 on PX4 for the analog 'airspeed' port. Set to 15 on the Pixhawk for the analog 'airspeed' port.

RNGFND_POS_X.Description: X position of the first rangefinder in body frame. Positive X is forward of the origin. Use the zero range datum point if supplied.

RNGFND_POS_Y.Description: Y position of the first rangefinder in body frame. Positive Y is to the right of the origin. Use the zero range datum point if supplied.

RNGFND_POS_Z.Description: Z position of the first rangefinder in body frame. Positive Z is down from the origin. Use the zero range datum point if supplied.

RNGFND_PWRRNG.Description: This parameter sets the estimated terrain distance in meters above which the sensor will be put into a power saving mode (if available). A value of zero means power saving is not enabled

Some analog rangefinders (such as the SF/02) have their own internal voltage regulators so they are not ratiometric.

RNGFND_SETTLE.Description: The time in milliseconds that the rangefinder reading takes to settle. This is only used when a STOP_PIN is specified. It determines how long we have to wait for the rangefinder to give a reading after we set the STOP_PIN high. For a sonar rangefinder with a range of around 7m this would need to be around 50 milliseconds to allow for the sonar pulse to travel to the target and back again.

RNGFND_STOP_PIN.Description: Digital pin that enables/disables rangefinder measurement for an analog rangefinder. A value of -1 means no pin. If this is set, then the pin is set to 1 to enable the rangefinder and set to 0 to disable it. This can be used to ensure that multiple sonar rangefinders don't interfere with each other.

RNGFND_TYPE.Description: What type of rangefinder device that is connected

RPM2_SCALING.Description: Scaling factor between sensor reading and RPM.

RPM2_TYPE.Description: What type of RPM sensor is connected

RPM_MIN_QUAL.Description: Minimum data quality to be used

RPM_SCALING.Description: Scaling factor between sensor reading and RPM.

RPM_TYPE.Description: What type of RPM sensor is connected

RSSI_ANA_PIN.Description: This selects an analog pin where the receiver RSSI voltage will be read.

RSSI_CHANNEL.Description: The channel number where RSSI will be output by the radio receiver (5 and above).

RSSI_CHAN_HIGH.Description: This is the PWM value in microseconds that the radio receiver will put on the RSSI_CHANNEL when the signal strength is the strongest. Since some radio receivers put out inverted values from what you might otherwise expect, this isn't necessarily a higher value than RSSI_CHAN_LOW.

RSSI_CHAN_LOW.Description: This is the PWM value in microseconds that the radio receiver will put on the RSSI_CHANNEL when the signal strength is the weakest. Since some radio receivers put out inverted values from what you might otherwise expect, this isn't necessarily a lower value than RSSI_CHAN_HIGH.

RSSI_PIN_HIGH.Description: This is the voltage value that the radio receiver will put on the RSSI_ANA_PIN when the signal strength is the strongest. Since some radio receivers put out inverted values from what you might otherwise expect, this isn't necessarily a higher value than RSSI_PIN_LOW.

RSSI_PIN_LOW.Description: This is the voltage value that the radio receiver will put on the RSSI_ANA_PIN when the signal strength is the weakest. Since some radio receivers put out inverted values from what you might otherwise expect, this isn't necessarily a lower value than RSSI_PIN_HIGH.

RSSI_TYPE.Description: Radio Receiver RSSI type. If your radio receiver supports RSSI of some kind, set it here, then set its associated RSSI_XXXXX parameters, if any.

SCHED_DEBUG.Description: Set to non-zero to enable scheduler debug messages. When set to show "Slips" the scheduler will display a message whenever a scheduled task is delayed due to too much CPU load. When set to ShowOverruns the scheduled will display a message whenever a task takes longer than the limit promised in the task table.

SCHED_LOOP_RATE.Description: This controls the rate of the main control loop in Hz. This should only be changed by developers. This only takes effect on restart. Values over 400 are considered highly experimental.

SERIAL0_BAUD.Description: The baud rate used on the USB console. The APM2 can support all baudrates up to 115, and also can support 500. The PX4 can support rates of up to 1500. If you setup a rate you cannot support on APM2 and then can't connect to your board you should load a firmware from a different vehicle type. That will reset all your parameters to defaults.

SERIAL0_PROTOCOL.Description: Control what protocol to use on the console.

SERIAL1_BAUD.Description: The baud rate used on the Telem1 port. The APM2 can support all baudrates up to 115, and also can support 500. The PX4 can support rates of up to 1500. If you setup a rate you cannot support on APM2 and then can't connect to your board you should load a firmware from a different vehicle type. That will reset all your parameters to defaults.

SERIAL1_PROTOCOL.Description: Control what protocol to use on the Telem1 port. Note that the Frsky options require external converter hardware. See the wiki for details.

SERIAL2_BAUD.Description: The baud rate of the Telem2 port. The APM2 can support all baudrates up to 115, and also can support 500. The PX4 can support rates of up to 1500. If you setup a rate you cannot support on APM2 and then can't connect to your board you should load a firmware from a different vehicle type. That will reset all your parameters to defaults.

SERIAL2_PROTOCOL.Description: Control what protocol to use on the Telem2 port. Note that the Frsky options require external converter hardware. See the wiki for details.

SERIAL3_BAUD.Description: The baud rate used for the Serial 3 (GPS). The APM2 can support all baudrates up to 115, and also can support 500. The PX4 can support rates of up to 1500. If you setup a rate you cannot support on APM2 and then can't connect to your board you should load a firmware from a different vehicle type. That will reset all your parameters to defaults.

SERIAL3_PROTOCOL.Description: Control what protocol Serial 3 (GPS) should be used for. Note that the Frsky options require external converter hardware. See the wiki for details.

SERIAL4_BAUD.Description: The baud rate used for Serial4. The APM2 can support all baudrates up to 115, and also can support 500. The PX4 can support rates of up to 1500. If you setup a rate you cannot support on APM2 and then can't connect to your board you should load a firmware from a different vehicle type. That will reset all your parameters to defaults.

SERIAL4_PROTOCOL.Description: Control what protocol Serial4 port should be used for. Note that the Frsky options require external converter hardware. See the wiki for details.

SERIAL5_BAUD.Description: The baud rate used for Serial5. The APM2 can support all baudrates up to 115, and also can support 500. The PX4 can support rates of up to 1500. If you setup a rate you cannot support on APM2 and then can't connect to your board you should load a firmware from a different vehicle type. That will reset all your parameters to defaults.

SERIAL5_PROTOCOL.Description: Control what protocol Serial5 port should be used for. Note that the Frsky options require external converter hardware. See the wiki for details.

SERVO_AUTO_TRIM.Description: This enables automatic servo trim in flight. Servos will be trimed in stabilized flight modes when the aircraft is close to level. Changes to servo trim will be saved every 10 seconds and will persist between flights.

SERVO_RATE.Description: This sets the default output rate in Hz for all outputs.

SERVO10_FUNCTION.Description: Function assigned to this servo. Seeing this to Disabled(0) will setup this output for control by auto missions or MAVLink servo set commands. any other value will enable the corresponding function

SERVO10_MAX.Description: maximum PWM pulse width in microseconds. Typically 1000 is lower limit, 1500 is neutral and 2000 is upper limit.

SERVO10_MIN.Description: minimum PWM pulse width in microseconds. Typically 1000 is lower limit, 1500 is neutral and 2000 is upper limit.

SERVO10_REVERSED.Description: Reverse servo operation. Set to 0 for normal operation. Set to 1 to reverse this output channel.

SERVO10_TRIM.Description: Trim PWM pulse width in microseconds. Typically 1000 is lower limit, 1500 is neutral and 2000 is upper limit.

SERVO_BLH_AUTO.Description: If set to 1 this auto-enables BLHeli pass-thru support for all multicopter motors

SERVO_BLH_DEBUG.Description: When set to 1 this enabled verbose debugging output over MAVLink when the blheli protocol is active. This can be used to diagnose failures.

SERVO_BLH_MASK.Description: Enable of BLHeli pass-thru servo protocol support to specific channels. This mask is in addition to motors enabled using SERVO_BLH_AUTO (if any)

SERVO_BLH_OTYPE.Description: When set to a non-zero value this overrides the output type for the output channels given by SERVO_BLH_MASK. This can be used to enable DShot on outputs that are not part of the multicopter motors group.

SERVO_BLH_TEST.Description: Setting SERVO_BLH_TEST to a motor number enables an internal test of the BLHeli ESC protocol to the corresponding ESC. The debug output is displayed on the USB console.

SERVO_BLH_TMOUT.Description: This sets the inactivity timeout for the BLHeli protocol in seconds. If no packets are received in this time normal MAVLink operations are resumed. A value of 0 means no timeout

SERVO_BLH_TRATE.Description: This sets the rate in Hz for requesting telemetry from ESCs. It is the rate per ESC. Setting to zero disables telemetry requests

SERVO_SBUS_RATE.Description: This sets the SBUS output frame rate in Hz.

SERVO_VOLZ_MASK.Description: Enable of volz servo protocol to specific channels

SPRAY_ENABLE.Description: Allows you to enable (1) or disable (0) the sprayer

SPRAY_PUMP_MIN.Description: Minimum pump speed expressed as a percentage

SPRAY_PUMP_RATE.Description: Desired pump speed when traveling 1m/s expressed as a percentage

SPRAY_SPEED_MIN.Description: Speed minimum at which we will begin spraying

SPRAY_SPINNER.Description: Spinner's rotation speed in PWM (a higher rate will disperse the spray over a wider area horizontally)

SRTL_ACCURACY.Description: SmartRTL accuracy. The minimum distance between points.

SRTL_POINTS.Description: SmartRTL maximum number of points on path. Set to 0 to disable SmartRTL.  100 points consumes about 3k of memory.
SRTL_POINTS.DisplayName: SmartRTL maximum number of points on path

STAT_BOOTCNT.Description: Number of times board has been booted

STAT_RESET.Description: Seconds since January 1st 2016 (Unix epoch+1451606400) since reset (set to 0 to reset statistics)

TCALBARO_EXP.Description: Learned exponent for barometer temperature correction

TCALENABLED.Description: Enable temperature calibration. Set to 0 to disable. Set to 1 to use learned values. Set to 2 to learn new values and use the values

TCALTEMP_MAX.Description: Maximum learned temperature. This is automatically set by the learning process

TCALTEMP_MIN.Description: Minimum learned temperature. This is automatically set by the learning process

TERRAIN_ENABLE.Description: enable terrain data. This enables the vehicle storing a database of terrain data on the SD card. The terrain data is requested from the ground station as needed, and stored for later use on the SD card. To be useful the ground station must support TERRAIN_REQUEST messages and have access to a terrain database, such as the SRTM database.

TERRAIN_SPACING.Description: Distance between terrain grid points in meters. This controls the horizontal resolution of the terrain data that is stored on te SD card and requested from the ground station. If your GCS is using the worldwide SRTM database then a resolution of 100 meters is appropriate. Some parts of the world may have higher resolution data available, such as 30 meter data available in the SRTM database in the USA. The grid spacing also controls how much data is kept in memory during flight. A larger grid spacing will allow for a larger amount of data in memory. A grid spacing of 100 meters results in the vehicle keeping 12 grid squares in memory with each grid square having a size of 2.7 kilometers by 3.2 kilometers. Any additional grid squares are stored on the SD once they are fetched from the GCS and will be demand loaded as needed.

TMODE_ACTION1.Description: This is the action taken for the left action button

TMODE_ACTION2.Description: This is the action taken for the right action button

TMODE_ACTION3.Description: This is the action taken for the power button

TMODE_ACTION4.Description: This is the action taken for the left action button while the mode button is pressed

TMODE_ACTION5.Description: This is the action taken for the right action button while the mode button is pressed

TMODE_ACTION6.Description: This is the action taken for the power button while the mode button is pressed

TMODE_ENABLE.Description: tmode (or "toy" mode) gives a simplified user interface designed for mass market drones. Version1 is for the SkyViper V2450GPS. Version2 is for the F412 based boards

TMODE_FLAGS.Description: Bitmask of flags to change the behaviour of tmode. DisarmOnLowThrottle means to disarm if throttle is held down for 1 second when landed. ArmOnHighThrottle means to arm if throttle is above 80% for 1 second. UpgradeToLoiter means to allow takeoff in LOITER mode by switching to ALT_HOLD, then auto-upgrading to LOITER once GPS is available. RTLStickCancel means that on large stick inputs in RTL mode that LOITER mode is engaged

TMODE_LEFT.Description: This is the action taken for the left button (mode button) being pressed

TMODE_LEFT_LONG.Description: This is the action taken for a long press of the left button (home button)

TMODE_LOAD_FILT.Description: This filters the load test output. A value of 1 means no filter. 2 means values are repeated once. 3 means values are repeated 3 times, etc

TMODE_LOAD_MUL.Description: This scales the load test output, as a value between 0 and 1

TMODE_LOAD_TYPE.Description: This sets the type of load test

TMODE_MODE1.Description: This is the initial mode when the vehicle is first turned on. This mode is assumed to not require GPS

TMODE_MODE2.Description: This is the secondary mode. This mode is assumed to require GPS

TMODE_RIGHT.Description: This is the action taken for the right button (RTL) being pressed

TMODE_TMAX.Description: This sets the thrust multiplier when voltage is low

TMODE_TMIN.Description: This sets the thrust multiplier when voltage is high

TMODE_TRIM_AUTO.Description: This is the amount of automatic stick trim that can be applied when disarmed with sticks not moving. It is a PWM limit value away from 1500

TMODE_VMAX.Description: This is the battery voltage above which thrust min is used

TMODE_VMIN.Description: This is the battery voltage below which no output limiting is done

VISO_POS_X.Description: X position of the camera in body frame. Positive X is forward of the origin.
VISO_POS_X.DisplayName: Visual odometry camera X position offset

VISO_POS_Y.Description: Y position of the camera in body frame. Positive Y is to the right of the origin.
VISO_POS_Y.DisplayName: Visual odometry camera Y position offset

VISO_POS_Z.Description: Z position of the camera in body frame. Positive Z is down from the origin.
VISO_POS_Z.DisplayName: Visual odometry camera Z position offset

WENC2_CPR.Description: WheelEncoder 2 counts per full revolution of the wheel

WENC2_POS_X.Description: X position of the center of the second wheel in body frame. Positive X is forward of the origin.

WENC2_POS_Y.Description: Y position of the center of the second wheel in body frame. Positive Y is to the right of the origin.

WENC2_POS_Z.Description: Z position of the center of the second wheel in body frame. Positive Z is down from the origin.

WENC2_TYPE.Description: What type of WheelEncoder sensor is connected

WENC_CPR.Description: WheelEncoder counts per full revolution of the wheel

WENC_POS_X.Description: X position of the center of the wheel in body frame. Positive X is forward of the origin.

WENC_POS_Y.Description: Y position of the center of the wheel in body frame. Positive Y is to the right of the origin.

WENC_POS_Z.Description: Z position of the center of the wheel in body frame. Positive Z is down from the origin.

WENC_TYPE.Description: What type of WheelEncoder is connected

WINCH__POS_P.Description: Winch control position error P gain
WINCH__POS_P.DisplayName: Winch control position error P gain

WINCH__RATE_D.Description: Winch control D gain.  Compensates for short-term change in desired rate vs actual

WINCH__RATE_FILT.Description: Winch control input filter.  Lower values reduce noise but add delay.

WINCH__RATE_I.Description: Winch control I gain.  Corrects long term error between the desired rate (in rad/s) and actual

WINCH__RATE_IMAX.Description: Winch control I gain maximum.  Constrains the output (range -1 to +1) that the I term will generate

WINCH__RATE_MAX.Description: Winch deploy or retract rate maximum.  Set to maximum rate with no load.
WINCH__RATE_MAX.DisplayName: Winch deploy or retract rate maximum

WINCH__RATE_P.Description: Winch control rate P gain.  Converts rate error (in radians/sec) to pwm output (in the range -1 to +1)

WPNAV_ACCEL.Description: Defines the horizontal acceleration in cm/s/s used during missions

WPNAV_ACCEL_Z.Description: Defines the vertical acceleration in cm/s/s used during missions

WPNAV_RADIUS.Description: Defines the distance from a waypoint, that when crossed indicates the wp has been hit.

WPNAV_RFND_USE.Description: This controls if waypoint missions use rangefinder for terrain following
WPNAV_RFND_USE.DisplayName: Waypoint missions use rangefinder for terrain following

WPNAV_SPEED.Description: Defines the speed in cm/s which the aircraft will attempt to maintain horizontally during a WP mission

WPNAV_SPEED_DN.Description: Defines the speed in cm/s which the aircraft will attempt to maintain while descending during a WP mission

WPNAV_SPEED_UP.Description: Defines the speed in cm/s which the aircraft will attempt to maintain while climbing during a WP mission
